Sorry John, but most respectfully, the problem is not just the lawyers.

I was an ADA from '94 to '97. I went back in Dec. 2011. I toured the gleaming (and sinking) Bx Hall of Justice. I reconnected with ADAs from back in the day and met ones fresh out.

The problem is that the Bronx has never had enough judges, courtrooms, jurors, clerks, CO's, inmate buses, or defense lawyers. The Bronx barely had enough ADAs back in the '90s, and it sounds like they may have even fewer now.

And this lack of resources perpetuates and attitude and mentality where everyone walks around saying "the system is broken, what can I do?" Glaberson has hit that nail on the head. That mentality must end. Otherwise, the Bronx will always have a third world criminal justice system.

Blaming it on the lawyers ignores the problem and demeans the people of Bronx, possibly the most ethnically diverse community on the planet Earth. Things must change. The powers that be have got to stop treating the Bronx like a third world country.
Should we become like your state? Stop crying about what state workers have and fight to get back what you once had and have lost because of greed.

At a time when there has been a public outcry about how too many young men are incarcerated, it makes sense that a District Attorney who can't seem to get convictions might actually be popular in the community.

DAG, the problem is so much worse in the Bronx because justice in the Bronx is the victim of 20 years of neglect. I was a Bronx ADA from 1/94 to 1/97. SAA is right. When I started, which was during the early years of the assault on quality of life crimes, the system was just beginning to digest the first wave of arrests. My memory has clouded, but I recall 40k docketed arrests in 1994. That number increased at least 10k per year each year I was there. Which, if I my memory is correct, means that the number of cases shoehorned into the system doubled in the '90s with no corresponding increase in resources to deal with them. From '94 to '97, while the amount of new cases skyrocketed, I saw no increase in judges, courtrooms, jurors, clerks, CO's, inmate buses, or defense lawyers. The Bronx barely had enough ADAs back in the '90s, and it sounds like they may have even fewer now.

The DA's office is filled with smart, skilled, compassionate lawyers. The bench is made up of dedicated, caring and wise judges like Boyle and Alvarado. There are many who care, but there are as many who perpetuate the mentality that "the system is broken, what can I do?" That is the problem in a nutshell. Everyone sees the elephant in the room, but no bothers to address it, feed it, water it, or do anything about it.

I am hopeful that Glaberson's piece will at least get some attention paid to the Bronx, but it has been eighteen years and I am starting to get a little jaded....

City Council speaker Christine Quinn’s seeming agreement that relocating elders from their long held homes in order to make space for large families on the NYCHA waiting list is astonishing. Has she considered the grief, confusion and pain that many older residents would experience from this? “It isn’t all that complicated.” Ms. Quinn? It is if you put yourself in their shoes.
I offer instead reviving the Mitchell-Lama Co-op Housing Program. With their low and middle income limits, tax abatement, low cost to buy in, and low carrying charges, these buildings offer affordable housing to me and my neighbors. We have enough left in our paychecks to give our children the opportunities to grow into the valued adults our society needs. We are able to have multiple generations living in one building - a vertical village - because our children can afford to move in and raise their families here as well. Revive the Mitchell-Lama co-op program. It’s a program that works.
Regina Gradess

I don't think you can just move someone out of their apartment, one that they have probably lived in for multiple decades, without labeling it as an eviction. Yes, they will be given a new apartment, but the fact remains that they will be displaced and forced to pack up and leave their home. It is, simply put, an eviction. And the only basis for the eviction is that they are "older residents" who have more bedrooms than people in their family.

I get it: there is wasted space that could be put to better use. But to say this is anything less than an eviction is wrong.

As to people renting out their rooms on AirBnb.... are you kidding me??? People who use Airbnb probably aren't interested in staying in the NYCHA housing projects!!! If the rooms are being legitimately rented out for roommate situations, however, what's the problem with that? In fact I think it helps solve the lack of affordable housing issue by providing people with inexpensive, habitable living solutions.
